response.answer_text: Have you ever tried to push your finger into a piece of wood? It’s pretty tough. But wood is actually made up of layers of fibres.  Nails push themselves between the fibres - they don’t make much of a hole, they squeeze the fibers out of the way. Thats why nails are pointed, but not sharp - so they don’t cut the fibres, they push between them. So, all those fibres create friction against the nail, stopping it being pulled out. The longer the nail, and the harder the wood, the more friction there is. Yes, you can “just pull them out” using a nail puller or hammer, but it’s not easy - and they certainly don’t usually fall out on their own.
